headline: Corrections & Amplifications
summary: Corrections & Amplifications for the edition of Jan. 9, 2019

headline: China’s Currency Proves a Surprise Oasis of Calm
summary: Despite recent turmoil in financial markets, the Chinese yuan has been surprisingly stable, as trade talks between Beijing and Washington continue and other pressures eased.

headline: Who Is More Macho?
summary: Trump and Democrats talk past one another again on immigration.

headline: Democratic Leaders Denounce Wall and Trump ‘Hostage’ Tactics
summary: House Speaker Nancy Pelosi and Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer said a wall on the Mexican border would be a waste, and accused the president of manufacturing a crisis amid the government shutdown.

headline: Key Numbers Behind Immigration
summary: Republicans and Democrats have different views on the extent of the problem associated with undocumented immigrants and how to address the issue. Here is a look at some of the data.

headline: Herbalife CEO Goudis Resigns
summary: Herbalife Nutrition’s chief executive has resigned after the company said it discovered comments he made prior to becoming CEO that were inconsistent with its standards.

headline: Carlos Ghosn in Wonderland
summary: The case against the former Nissan CEO gets no stronger with age.

headline: Sumner Redstone, Family Settle Legal Dispute With Former Companion
summary: Media mogul Sumner Redstone and his family have agreed to settle their long-running legal dispute with his former live-in companion, Manuela Herzer, less than a week before one of the cases was scheduled for trial.

headline: Apple’s Tim Cook Gets 22% Increase in Pay
summary: Chief Executive Tim Cook received the big boost in compensation for fiscal 2018, when the iPhone maker blew past annual sales and profit goals but faced slowing momentum for its most popular device.

headline: Herb Kelleher
summary: The capitalist who ‘democratized the skies.’

headline: A California-Nevada Tax Brawl
summary: The Supreme Court gets another chance on state sovereign immunity.

headline: Europe’s Boom That Wasn’t
summary: A downturn looms before the upturn has fully materialized.

headline: Price Drugs According to What They Do
summary: A simple reform to improve outcomes and control costs.

headline: Have We Got a Carbon Tax ‘Dividend’ for You
summary: Rent seekers, virtue signalers and green lobbyists will love it. Taxpayers not so much.

headline: What Trump Means by ‘America First’
summary: His historical antecedent? Not Charles Lindbergh but the ‘belligerent isolationism’ of Sen. William Borah.

headline: High Tax Rates Aren’t Optimal
summary: Nobody really thinks a top rate of 70% or 80% is a good idea in the real world.

headline: Democrats Contend With the ‘Anger Translator’
summary: Nancy Pelosi will have a hard time keeping the ultraprogressives in her caucus quiet.

headline: Could Emergency Powers Build the Wall?
summary: Trump says he can move without consent of Congress, but legal scholars are divided.

headline: ‘The Longest Line on the Map’ Review: The End of the Road
summary: It seemed like a great idea, linking the Americas with a rail line or highway. Landscape challenges and corruption got in the way. Charles R. Morris reviews “The Longest Line on the Map” by Eric Rutkow.

headline: U.S. Signals Off-Ramp for Sanctions Against Venezuelan TV Station
summary: Caracas-based pro-government television news network Globovisión Tele CA and a related Florida company were added Tuesday to the U.S. sanctions list because they are owned by Raúl Gorrín, who Washington has accused of profiting from illicit access to the country’s broken currency market.

headline: Cuomo’s Talk of Tearing Up MTA Timed to Upcoming Budget Season
summary: Gov. Andrew Cuomo wants to overhaul the Metropolitan Transportation Authority.

headline: Lawmakers Grill Murphy Officials Over Handling of Assault Claim
summary: New Jersey legislators asked members of Gov. Phil Murphy’s campaign and administration about their handling of a sexual-assault allegation against a state employee, focusing on one issue: Should they have done more?

headline: Notable & Quotable: The Courts!
summary: ‘We’ve lost everything, including the right to free and fair elections.’

headline: Supreme Court Rules Against Mysterious Foreign Company
summary: The Supreme Court rejected an unnamed foreign company’s effort to avoid penalties for defying a grand jury subpoena that appears to be part of special counsel Robert Mueller’s inquiry into Russian electoral interference.

headline: Departures Resume From London Heathrow Following Drone Sighting
summary: Heathrow Airport, one of the world’s busiest aviation hubs, temporarily halted departing flights late Tuesday after a nearby drone sighting, the second shuttering of a London airport due to drones in less than three weeks.

headline: The U.S. Has Always Chosen World Bank Presidents—Will It This Time?
summary: The unexpected resignation of the World Bank’s president could accelerate a divide among major economies over the leadership of the world’s largest development-finance institution.

headline: Blackstone-Backed Exeter Finance Files for IPO
summary: Blackstone bought subprime auto lender Exeter Finance Corp. from fellow private-equity firm Navigation Capital Partners in 2011.

headline: The 380,000
summary: Just how many unnecessary employees does the federal government employ?

headline: Ethics and Campaign Reforms on Horizon in Albany
summary: New York Democrats, who control the state Senate for the first time in a decade, are planning to roll out legislation on voting and campaign finance Wednesday.

headline: Biotech Proposes Paying for Pricey Drugs by Installment
summary: A Boston-area biotech says it may have a found a way to bring off the expected seven-figure cost of its experimental gene therapy: paying on installment.

headline: ‘Fritz Ascher: Expressionist’ Review: Finally at Home With the Greats
summary: An exhibition at the Grey Art Gallery places the under-the-radar Ascher squarely in the canon of 20th-century German artists.

headline: Dollar Climbs as Investors Reconsider Rate Outlook
summary: The dollar ticked higher Tuesday, showing tentative signs of stabilizing after Jerome Powell’s comments last week bolstered investors’ confidence that the Fed will be cautious about raising interest rates this year.

headline: PG&E Replaces Head of Electric System
summary: A top executive overseeing the utility’s electric division is leaving the company amid rising concerns about its financial health and safety practices following the recent California wildfires.

headline: ‘Aeonic’ by Balsam Range Review: Bluegrass That’s Ready to Grow
summary: The eclectic group from North Carolina proves it could leap to great popularity with an album that blends deep musical traditions with modern touches.

headline: U.S. Carbon Emissions Rose 3.4% in 2018 as Economy Surged
summary: U.S. carbon emissions rose 3.4% in 2018, after three years of declines, as the effects of a strong economy outstripped a sharp decline in the number of power plants burning coal to generate electricity.

headline: A Journey With Lung Cancer
summary: Two years ago, Terri Ann DiJulio was diagnosed with lung cancer—for the second time. In the 12 years since her first bout with the disease, better early-detection methods and more treatments had emerged.

headline: Kavanaugh Delivers First Opinion as Ginsburg Is Absent
summary: Shades of the past and future permeated Supreme Court proceedings, as Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg’s chair remained vacant while she recuperates from cancer, and new Justice Brett Kavanaugh delivered his first opinion.

headline: Oil Extends Rebound as Oversupply Fears Ease
summary: Oil prices climbed for the seventh consecutive session, extending a recent rebound to start 2019.

headline: Entry Exam to City’s Top High Schools Underrates Girls, Study Finds
summary: New York City’s eight specialized public high schools have long accepted fewer girls than boys. A study drawing new attention to that disparity finds the entry exam underestimates girls’ academic success.

headline: U.S. Government Bonds Fall Amid Auctions
summary: Bond prices dropped amid signs that risk sentiment is improving while the Treasury Department completed the first of three auctions this week.

headline: Manafort Lawyers Reveal New Details of His Links to Kiev Associate
summary: Attorneys for Paul Manafort inadvertently disclosed that the former Trump campaign chairman gave 2016 presidential polling data to a Kiev associate U.S. officials have linked to Russian intelligence and may have discussed a Ukraine peace plan with him.

headline: New York City to Offer More Health Care to the Uninsured
summary: In a bid to lessen the burden on emergency rooms, Mayor Bill de Blasio announced a plan to expand health care to the city’s uninsured.

headline: Small-Cap Stocks Take On New Shine
summary: Small-capitalization companies are projected to notch another year of big profit gains, potentially making their shares a haven for investors as earnings at larger firms slow.

headline: Eddie Lampert Wants to Save Sears But Mall Owners Say Don’t Bother
summary: Many landlords say Sears lost touch with consumers years ago and that the department-store chain’s plan to keep stores open rather than pursue going-out-of-business sales is unlikely to succeed.

headline: Baltimore Mayor Picks New Orleans’s Police Chief to Lead Troubled Force
summary: Baltimore’s mayor nominated New Orleans’s top cop to run the city’s troubled police department, a day after the withdrawal of her first pick brought fresh upheaval in one of the nation’s most violent cities.

headline: Boeing, Airbus Miss 2018 Jet Delivery Targets
summary: Both aerospace giants failed to deliver all the jets they had once planned to make in 2018, showing how production problems are holding back the two top plane makers as demand for airliners soars.

headline: Zuckerberg’s Personal 2019 Challenge: Talk More About Tech’s Problems
summary: Mark Zuckerberg last year boldly announced his personal challenge was to fix Facebook. This year the Facebook CEO and founder is setting a more modest goal. In a blog post, Mr. Zuckerberg said this year he plans to host a series of public discussions on the role of technology in society.

headline: Global Growth to Lose Momentum This Year, World Bank Says
summary: The World Bank cut its forecasts for global growth in 2019 and 2020, citing a worsening set of factors from trade tensions to financial-market instability to currency challenges in a number of emerging markets.

headline: Dotdash, Riding Wave of Search Traffic, Acquires New Sites
summary: The publisher, which owns sites including The Spruce and Verywell, is buying two beauty websites, Byrdie and Mydomaine, as annual revenue passes $100 million.

headline: Canadian Truck Driver Pleads Guilty in Deadly Hockey Bus Crash
summary: The truck driver involved in a deadly crash last year with a bus carrying members of a rural Canadian junior hockey team pleaded guilty on Tuesday to all of the charges against him.

headline: The Drug Price-Control Threat
summary: Trump, Sanders and Warren sound the same themes. Watch out.

headline: Cancer Deaths Decline 27% Over 25 Years
summary: Deaths from cancer dropped 27% over a quarter century, resulting in an estimated 2.6 million fewer cancer deaths during that period, according to a new report from researchers at the American Cancer Society.

headline: The Saints Already Thrashed the Eagles. Will the Playoffs Be More of the Same?
summary: After losing to New Orleans 48-7 in the regular season, Philadelphia faces long odds in the rematch.

headline: Costly iPhone Canary and a U.S.-China Rift
summary: Can and should trade relations with China be divorced from U.S. national security and other noneconomic interests?

headline: Infrastructure Needs Meet the Pork Barrel
summary: Congress and the Trump administration should address the Highway Trust Fund, the airport passenger facility charge and ensure all funds in the Harbor Maintenance Trust Fund are being used for their intended purpose.

headline: Australia Weighing Asylum for Saudi Teen Who Fled Family
summary: Australia says it will consider any application for asylum from a Saudi teen who fled from her family while traveling and took to social media appealing for her safety.

headline: Harvey Weinstein’s Trial Set to Begin in Early May
summary: Former Hollywood producer Harvey Weinstein is scheduled to go to trial on sex-crime charges May 6 in state court in Manhattan, court filings show.

headline: Beijing’s Curious Silence on the Syria Withdrawal
summary: For all its bluster, China relies on the U.S.-led international order to secure its own interests.

headline: EU Imposes Fresh Sanctions on Iran Over Assassination Plots
summary: The European Union has imposed its first sanctions against Iran since the nuclear accord was implemented three years ago, as European diplomats warned their Iranian counterparts that the bloc wouldn’t tolerate further alleged Iranian attacks and assassinations in Europe.

headline: China Approves DowDuPont’s Genetically Modified Soybeans
summary: China’s approval of DowDuPont’s new genetically modified soybeans will open another front in U.S. farmers’ long-running war against hard-to-kill weeds.

headline: Russian Lawyer Charged With Obstruction of Justice
summary: The Russian lawyer who met with Trump campaign officials at Trump Tower in 2016 has been charged with obstruction of justice stemming from her role in a federal money-laundering case.

headline: Verizon Adds Subscribers as Device Makers Struggle
summary: Verizon Communications continued to expand its base of wireless phone subscribers in the final quarter of 2018, a period in which smartphone makers Apple and Samsung Electronics have warned investors they would fall short of expectations.

headline: Should Rugs Stay Out of the Kitchen? Designers Duke it Out
summary: Some interior designers think the kitchen is no place for a crumb-catching carpet. Others believe they can work around the ick factor.

headline: Bank of Canada Expected to Keep Rates on Hold Amid Lower Crude Prices
summary: The Bank of Canada is widely expected to keep its benchmark overnight interest rate on hold at a policy announcement Wednesday, giving officials more time to monitor the impact of low oil prices and financial-market turbulence on the Canadian economy.

headline: The Psychiatrist Can See Your Child Now, Virtually
summary: With a growing shortage of psychiatrists and other mental-health professionals for children and adolescents, more health-care providers are turning to technology to fill the gap.

headline: WeWork Raises Additional Capital From SoftBank
summary: WeWork secured an additional $2 billion from SoftBank Group, a smaller amount than the Japanese company had previously planned to invest in the co-working space provider.

headline: Microsoft’s Brief Comeback
summary: Microsoft Corp.’s reign as world’s most valuable company was short, but Amazon.com’s could be shorter.

headline: Carlos Ghosn’s Lawyer Launches Campaign to Clear His Client
summary: Carlos Ghosn’s lawyer took aim at Japanese prosecutors, arguing they rushed to judgment and had no basis for their lengthy detention of the auto executive.

headline: Saudi Arabia Edges Toward Bet on Booming U.S. Energy Sector
summary: Saudi Arabia is nearing a deal to invest in U.S. liquefied natural gas, a landmark decision for the kingdom which in the past had been a huge supplier of energy to America.

headline: U.S. Job Openings Fell in November
summary: The number of unfilled jobs in the U.S. fell in November to the lowest level since June, though openings still exceeded unemployed Americans.

headline: MetLife CEO Steven Kandarian to Retire in April
summary: MetLife President and Chief Executive Steven Kandarian is turning over the reins of the nation’s second-biggest life insurer to a top lieutenant, Michel Khalaf, as he sets April 30 for his delayed retirement.

headline: Workforce-Training Program Shares Secret to Students’ Success: Grit
summary: Year Up New York trains students in fields such as financial services and software engineering along with soft skills such as networking, making presentations and how to shake hands.

headline: Apple’s Answer to Slower iPhone Sales? The Trade In
summary: The tech giant is pushing a trade-in program that often pays more than carriers do to persuade people to exchange older devices.

headline: What’s Up With Men Who Don’t Wear Coats in Winter?
summary: You’ve seen them: those stubborn guys who refuse to dress appropriately for the weather. We attempt to understand their ‘reasoning.’

headline: Germany Shows Symptoms of Deeper Economic Pain
summary: Fresh signs of a weakening German economy are raising fears that last year’s slowdown could spill into 2019, deepening the challenges facing policy makers.

headline: Mattel Plans Live-Action Barbie Film
summary: Mattel wants to return Barbie to the big screen and plans to create the first live-action feature film starring the character from its iconic toy franchise.

headline: AmEx Suspends a Director in Foreign-Exchange Pricing Probe
summary: American Express suspended a director in its foreign-exchange department as part of its investigation into pricing practices in the division.

headline: Emily Blunt and John Krasinski Buy One of Brooklyn’s Priciest Properties
summary: Actors Emily Blunt and John Krasinski paid about $11 million for a full floor in a luxury Brooklyn condominium building, according to people familiar with the deal. The transaction is one of the largest ever done in the New York City borough, public records show.

headline: Hulu Reports More Than 25 Million Subscribers in 2018
summary: Hulu had more than 25 million subscribers at the end of 2018, up by eight million from the year earlier, the streaming service announced.

headline: U.S., China Narrow Differences on Trade
summary: The U.S. and China made progress on narrowing their differences on trade issues and purchases of U.S. goods and services, though the two sides are far from striking a deal.

headline: The 16 Best Denim Looks for Him and Her
summary: Classic jeans paired with modern jackets and sweaters make for a winning combo.

headline: Billionaire Henry Kravis Asks $46 Million for Colorado Ranch
summary: The KKR co-founder is selling a property with a Greg Norman-designed golf course and helipad that is located more than an hour from Aspen.

headline: Nissan Needs a New Carlos Ghosn
summary: Carlos Ghosn won his spurs turning Nissan around in the early 2000s. Now the Japanese car maker needs an even more sophisticated turnaround artist.

headline: An Outdoorsy Home With Room to Grow
summary: A couple expanded and upgraded this 61-acre property in Salisbury, Conn., that comes with views of the Appalachian Trail. It is asking $3.95 million.

headline: Jazz Musician Kamasi Washington’s Favorite Things
summary: A cane, a saxophone and one-of-a-kind robes are among his favorite possessions.

headline: Barclays’s Badly Timed Activist Might Be Good For its Board
summary: It may be the wrong time for anything radical at Barclays, but a board seat might still be the right place for activist Edward Bramson.

headline: German Hacking Arrest Quells Fears Attack Was Foreign Backed
summary: German authorities have arrested a 20-year-old man suspected of being involved in the theft and online posting of data on hundreds of German politicians and other personalities.

headline: The 1948 Plymouth That Defeated the North Dakota Winter
summary: It sat in a field for 44 years, but two sisters who grew up with a car they call the Bomb got it running in time to play a role in a wedding.

headline: After 50 Long Days in Jail, Ghosn Is Sharp as He Prepares His Defense
summary: Former Nissan Chairman Carlos Ghosn spends little time obsessing over his former colleagues who gave prosecutors information about his alleged wrongdoing and instead focuses in meetings with his defense team on how to win the case.

headline: Photos: Wicked Weather Has Nothing on This Car
summary: A pair of sisters show off the 1948 Plymouth they dubbed the Bomb as teenagers and restored after it sat unused for 44 years.

headline: Joint Ventures: Greece Cultivates  Business Opportunities in Cannabis
summary: More entrepreneurs and investors see a boom in the growing and selling of legal cannabis in Europe. Greece could be one of the biggest winners.

headline: Stocks to Watch: Amazon, Union Pacific, Lennar, Loxo Oncology, IBM
summary: Amazon, Union Pacific, Lennar, and Loxo Oncology are among the stocks to watch on Tuesday.

headline: This Really Is the Next Revolution in TV Technology
summary: MicroLED is better looking, more efficient and more versatile than any previous display tech. Now all Samsung, Sony, LG and others have to do is figure out how to manufacture it affordably.

headline: Google to Lease Office Space in a Los Angeles Mall
summary: Google is planning to lease what is currently the Westside Pavilion in Los Angeles, the latest deal in which retail sites are seen as appealing locations for companies looking to attract and retain workers.

headline: Tying American Stocks to the Rest of the World
summary: The great decoupling of the American stock markets from the rest of the world was the story last summer. Was last month the start of a great recoupling, where investors should bet on the U.S. falling back in line with global market performance?

headline: Foreigners Funded Houston Development to Get Green Cards. They Were Duped, SEC Says
summary: Scores of foreign investors in pursuit of U.S. green cards poured nearly $50 million into what they thought was going to be a giant senior housing, luxury residential and retail project in a booming suburb of Houston.

headline: Canada’s Trade Deficit Widened In November
summary: Canada’s trade deficit more than doubled in November on a sharp drop in crude-oil exports.

headline: Investors Poised for Subtle Signs of De-Escalation as Trade Talks Proceed
summary: As U.S. trade negotiators meet with their Beijing counterparts, analysts are watching closely for even the smallest signs of progress.

headline: Pledges Made by Italy’s Populist Government Come Up Against Economic Reality
summary: Italy’s government has offered to shore up an ailing bank with public money, in a sharp U-turn after attacking mainstream politicians for years for bailing out Italian banks with taxpayers’ money.

headline: Two Sailors Missing, Another Is Killed in Hong Kong Tanker Explosion
summary: At least one sailor has died and two others are missing after a massive explosion on a tanker off the coast of Lamma Island in Hong Kong.

headline: Volatility Signal Flashes Red, Even as Stocks Rebound
summary: The futures curve tracking Wall Street’s “fear gauge,” the VIX, remains inverted, with contracts expiring in the near term more expensive than ones dated further out in the future, an indication that some investors expect wild price swings to continue.

headline: Nvidia Has Time to Get More Game
summary: Nvidia needs time to get its videogaming business back on track, and fortunately for the chip maker, $76 billion buys a lot of it.

headline: Small-Business Confidence in U.S. Economy Weakens
summary: The National Federation of Independent Business said its optimism index fell in December, a fourth straight month of declines, and the outlook on business conditions reached its lowest level since late 2016.

headline: Uber CEO Says Market Turmoil Won’t Derail IPO Plans
summary: Uber was internally on track to list this year, Dara Khosrowshahi said, having previously said he expected to seek a debut in the second half of 2019 in what would be one of the biggest public offerings planned for the year.

headline: U.K. Finds a Faulty Shipping Safety Net for Brexit
summary: With the March 29 deadline for the U.K. to separate from the European Union looming, the British government is scrambling to prevent a logistics nightmare that could bring shortages of essential goods.

headline: WeWork’s Not Working for SoftBank Anymore
summary: The Japanese tech giant slashed a planned investment in the shared-workspace provider, after backers of its nearly $100 billion Vision fund got cold feet.

headline: Chinese Bond Yields Hit Two-Year Low
summary: A weak economy has helped push down Chinese bond yields. To some investors that looks overdone, given a likely surge in government debt issuance and a stabilizing stock market.

headline: Samsung Echoes Apple’s Gloomy Outlook as Tech Woes Deepen
summary: Samsung expects its fourth-quarter operating profit will decline 29%, guidance that fell far below analysts’ estimates and the latest sign of challenges hitting the tech industry.

headline: What’s News: World-Wide
summary: What’s News: World-Wide

headline: Pepper...and Salt
summary: Pepper...and Salt

headline: Clemson Routs Alabama to Win National Championship
summary: Clemson wins the college football national championship, 44-16, defeating Alabama in the title game for the second time in three years.

headline: What’s News: Business & Finance
summary: What’s News: Business & Finance

headline: Sears Gets Another Lifeline: Lampert’s $4.4 Billion Bid Still Alive
summary: A bid to rescue the retailer from bankruptcy proceedings by Sears Holdings former CEO Edward Lampert is still alive, as an auction is set for Jan. 14.

headline: Senate Democrats Block Legislation to Press GOP on Shutdown
summary: Senate Democrats blocked the chamber from considering foreign-policy legislation in a bid to pressure Republicans to reopen the government, hours before President Trump was to make a national appeal to end the stalemate on the grounds of national security.

headline: Erdogan Rebuffs U.S. Call to Protect Kurds
summary: President Trump’s plans for a rapid withdrawal of American troops from Syria were thrown into disarray when Turkey’s president rejected a request to protect U.S. allies fighting in the region, and instead threatened military strikes against them.

headline: Democrats Introduce Bill Expanding Background Checks on Gun Sales
summary: Democrats’ long-pledged push to tighten the country’s gun laws will take center stage as lawmakers introduce legislation aimed at expanding background checks on gun sales.

headline: Stocks Advance for a Third Session
summary: Shares jumped on signs the U.S. and China made progress during their trade negotiations, with major U.S. indexes climbing about 1%.

headline: U.S. Sanctions Aim to Pressure Venezuela’s Maduro
summary: The Treasury Department sanctioned a Venezuelan network that allowed the owner of media giant Globovision and several state-connected businesspeople to illicitly make billions in profits.

headline: Facebook, Twitter Turn to Right-Leaning Groups to Help Referee Political Speech
summary: Advisers on touchy issues include Tony Perkins’ Family Research Council, Grover Norquist’s Americans for Tax Reform and, on the left, the Southern Poverty Law Center. Their involvement behind the scenes, designed to tamp down a furor over social media’s policing of content, has instead kicked up a new range of disputes.

headline: Are Those Gold Teeth or Did You Just Eat in the Gaudiest Place on Earth?
summary: An edible-gold arms race is on in the United Arab Emirates, and the upscale treats can be a mess to eat. ‘I had gold all over my teeth and my mouth.’

headline: Itzhak Perlman Became a Star on TV at Age 13
summary: The violinist and conductor beat postwar poverty in Israel to become a 16-time Grammy winner and Presidential Medal of Freedom recipient.

headline: How Clemson Emulated Silicon Valley to Win a National Title
summary: Just as the technology business became known for the relative youth of its executives—valuing skill over experience—Clemson typifies the sport’s growing embrace of quarterbacks straight out of high school.

headline: What’s the Rush? The Power of a Slow Morning
summary: As an antidote to our tech-obsessed society, slow-morning practitioners wake up early to meditate, read, exercise or do nothing at all.

headline: North Korean Leader’s Beijing Visit Underscores China’s Pivotal Role
summary: The timing of Kim Jong Un’s visit to Beijing at Chinese President Xi’s invitation suggests Beijing could see North Korea as leverage in its trade dispute with the U.S.

headline: WarnerMedia Puts Its Stake in New HQ Building Up for Sale, Before It Moves In
summary: WarnerMedia isn’t expected to move into its future Manhattan headquarters until later this year, but it is already looking to unload its stake in the brand-new building.

headline: Tech That Will Change Your Life in 2019
summary: An annual roundup of the technology that will affect your life in the year ahead: Mobile 5G will finally make its U.S. debut, providing more reasons than ever to cut the cord, and of course Harry Potter will unite wizards and teach us the true meaning of augmented reality.
